messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On Guillotine Separable Packings for the Two-dimensional Geometric Knapsack Problem

Paper Abstract: Abstract In two-dimensional geometric knapsack problem, we are given a set of nn axis-aligned rectangular items and an axis-aligned square-shaped knapsack. Each item has integral width, integral height and an associated integral profit. The goal is to find a (non-overlapping axis-aligned) packing of a maximum profit subset of rectangles into the knapsack. A well-studied and frequently used constraint in practice is to allow only packings that are guillotine separable, i.e., every rectangle in the packing can be obtained by recursively applying a sequence of edge-to-edge axis-parallel cuts that do not intersect any item of the solution. In this paper we study approximation algorithms for the geometric knapsack problem under guillotine cut constraints. We present polynomial time (1+蔚)1(1+\varepsilon)-approximation algorithms for the cases with and without allowing rotations by 90 degrees, assuming that all input numeric data are polynomially bounded in nn. In comparison, the best-known approximation factor for this setting is 3+蔚33+\varepsilon [Jansen-Zhang, SODA 2004], even in the cardinality case where all items have the same profit. Our main technical contribution is a structural lemma which shows that any guillotine packing can be converted into another structured guillotine packing with almost the same profit. In this packing, each item is completely contained in one of a constant number of boxes and \boldsymbol\boldsymbol\boldsymbol{\mathsf{L}}-shaped regions, inside which the items are placed by a simple greedy routine. In particular, we provide a clean sufficient condition when such a packing obeys the guillotine cut constraints which might be useful for other settings where these constraints are imposed.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "On guillotine cutting sequences",
        "Approximation schemes for maximum weight independent set of rectangles",
        "A quasi-PTAS for the two-dimensional geometric knapsack problem",
        "Color-coding",
        "A tabu search algorithm for large-scale guillotine (un) constrained two-dimensional cutting problems",
        "A structural lemma in 2-dimensional packing, and its implications on approximability",
        "Bin packing in multiple dimensions: inapproximability results and approximation schemes",
        "Improved approximation algorithm for two-dimensional bin packing",
        "A tale of two dimensional bin packing",
        "An exact two-dimensional non-guillotine cutting tree search procedure",
        "An eda for the 2d knapsack problem with guillotine constraint",
        "Packing 2-dimensional bins in harmony",
        "Fast approximation schemes for two-stage, two-dimensional bin packing",
        "A polynomial time approximation scheme for the multiple knapsack problem",
        "Approximation and online algorithms for multidimensional bin packing: A survey",
        "An algorithm for two-dimensional cutting problems",
        "Combining dynamic programming with filtering to solve a four-stage two-dimensional guillotine-cut bounded knapsack problem",
        "Pattern-based diving heuristics for a two-dimensional guillotine cutting-stock problem with leftovers",
        "Performance bounds for level-oriented two-dimensional packing algorithms",
        "Parameterized algorithms",
        "Algorithms for two-dimensional guillotine packing problems",
        "Exact algorithms for the two-dimensional guillotine knapsack",
        "Bin packing can be solved within 1+蔚11+\\varepsilon in linear time",
        "On efficient weighted rectangle packing with large resources",
        "Packing weighted rectangles into a square",
        "Modeling two-dimensional guillotine cutting problems via integer programming",
        "A tight (3/2+系italic-系\\epsilon) approximation for skewed strip packing",
        "Approximating geometric knapsack via l-packings",
        "Improved pseudo-polynomial-time approximation for strip packing",
        "Improved approximation algorithms for 2-dimensional knapsack: Packing into multiple l-shapes, spirals and more",
        "Multistage cutting stock problems of two and more dimensions",
        "A (5/3 + 蔚\\varepsilon)-approximation for unsplittable flow on a path: placing small tasks into boxes",
        "An exact algorithm for general, orthogonal, two-dimensional knapsack problems",
        "A (5/3 + 系italic-系\\epsilon)-approximation for strip packing",
        "Faster approximation schemes for the two-dimensional knapsack problem",
        "Approximation schemes for covering and packing problems in image processing and VLSI",
        "New approximability results for 2-dimensional packing problems",
        "A polynomial time approximation scheme for the square packing problem",
        "On rectangle packing: maximizing benefits",
        "A near-optimal solution to a two-dimensional cutting stock problem",
        "On guillotine separability of squares and rectangles",
        "Approximation algorithms for generalized multidimensional knapsack",
        "Packing squares into a square",
        "Partial enumeration algorithms for two-dimensional bin packing problem with guillotine constraints",
        "Breaking the barrier of 2 for the storage allocation problem",
        "Cutting glass",
        "A hybrid genetic algorithm for the two-dimensional cutting problem",
        "Group fairness for knapsack problems",
        "Two-dimensional bin packing problem with guillotine restrictions",
        "The two-dimensional cutting stock problem revisited",
        "A strip-packing algorithm with absolute performance bound 2",
        "Cutting and packing problems: a categorized, application-orientated research bibliography",
        "An exact best-first search procedure for the constrained rectangular guillotine knapsack problem",
        "A bidirectional building approach for the 2d constrained guillotine knapsack packing problem"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On Guillotine Separable Packings for the Two-dimensional Geometric Knapsack Problem, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
